thread.title: Fairfield Union pulls out double overtime thriller
thread.title_full: Fairfield Union pulls out double overtime thriller

title: Fairfield Union pulls out double overtime thriller
text:
Fairfield Union pulls out double overtime thriller Tom Wilson , Reporter 11:46 p.m. EDT October 22, 2015 Buy Photo Fairfield Union girls soccer coach Casey Bischof talks with his team after the pulled out thrilling 3-2 double overtime win over Athens in a Division II first-round tournament game. (Photo: Tom Wilson/Eagle-Gazette) Buy Photo 212 CONNECT 9 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
RUSHVILLE - The Fairfield Union girls soccer team had to feel like it was going back in time Thursday in its Division II sectional tournament opener against Athens. 
A year ago, the Falcons went to double overtime, then were forced to go to penalty kicks and eventually lost to the higher-seeded Bulldogs. 
On Thursday, Fairfield Union looked to be in great shape with a 2-0 lead with only 3:11 left in regulation, but Athens managed to score twice, the final goal coming with only 1:35 left, to force overtime. 
However, the Falcons — who are the No. 1 seed in the Southeast district — weren't about to let it happen again. 
Junior Parker Ruff scored the winning goal midway through the second overtime, and the Falcons were able to pull out a thrilling 3-2 victory over the visiting Bulldogs. 
“We were looking to score right there,” Fairfield Union coach Casey Bischof said. “We sent both of our center backs up and Theron Ruff crossed it in, and Parker Ruff does what she does best and knocked it into an empty when it went off the keeper.” 
Fairfield Union (14-1-1) advances to play third-seeded Unioto in a district semifinal at 5 p.m. Thursday at Logan High School. 
“I was so nervous and right before (that goal),” Parker Ruff said. “To be honest, I was about to ask out because I didn’t feel well, but they told me to go to the back side and I just stood there and I saw the keeper miss and somehow I was able to put it in. 
“I was so happy because there are three seniors on our team and I played the entire game for them because I don’t want to see them go yet. I knew when I scored, they weren’t leaving and I became emotional and started crying.” 
For Amber Lee, who gave the Falcons a 1-0 lead with 11:12 left in the first half, not scoring in the second overtime wasn’t an option because of what happened last season against the Bulldogs. 
“We were in this exact same situation last year against this same team and we lost in penalty kicks,” Lee said. “That is in the back of your mind, that you don’t want that to happen again. It gives you extra drive, and if you are tired, you have to kick it up another notch and keep going. 
“We felt like we dominated the whole game, but we got a couple of unlucky calls and they scored at the end, but we knew we if we played with heart we would be able to grind it out.” 
The Falcons took a 2-0 lead in the first half when standout freshman Taylor Davis scored on a breakaway goal. Fairfield Union just missed on several other scoring opportunities in the second half and in the first overtime. 
Bischof wasn’t pleased that Athens scored two goals to tie it up late in the game, but he knew the Bulldogs wouldn’t quit because of the history between the two teams. 
“When your backs are against the wall, you are going to give that fight, and I think we took it a little bit for granted,” Bischof said. “(Athens) moved a player up late in the game, and we kind of got ball-watching a little bit, and they were fighting for everything they have. 
“We told the girls it will take all heart to win it because we knew Athens would keep punching. We just needed to suck it up and find a way to win, and that’s what we did.” 
The Falcons dodged a huge bullet and they can breathe a sigh of relief. 
“Being a No. 1 seed, you have a bull's-eye on your back and you are going to get everyone’s best shot,” Lee said. “We have to be ready to go, and if we get the chance, we have to put teams away early like we should have (Thursday night).” 
twilson@lancastereaglegazette.com
